body.p:
Frankfort Ky
June 6th 1862
Hon B Magoffin
Sir
I have been in this city for some days past awaiting an interview with your Excellency in relation to my friend F M Searcy

The facts set forth in his petition are true I was a member of the first Grand Jury and his case was thoroughly investigated -- All of the testimony for the Commonwealth was adduced and upon a vote they failed to find an indictment

At the next term of the court of my own personal knowledge two of the Grand Jurors who had
been selected by the companies were voluntarily excused from service by the Judge and two others put in their stead of the court selection
The Judge telling the excused Members that a matter would come up in which a friend of theirs was --
The foreman of the Jury ^that found the indictment^ & one other member were cousins of the deceased Caperton
There is no politics in this case and after Mr Searcy, acquitted by the examining court generally sustained their finding
I ask you to pardon Mr Searcy and am positivey certain your action will be approved by our community
